key_points: Senate Republicans voted to block a bill to create a bipartisan commission to investigate the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.
Republican leaders argued the commission would duplicate other investigations and should also examine violence during last summer’s racial justice protests.
President Joe Biden expressed disbelief that anyone would vote against the commission, emphasizing the severity of the Capitol assault.
Six Republican Senators voted in favor of advancing the bill, but it failed to overcome the 60-vote filibuster threshold, effectively killing the measure.
Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer criticized the vote, suggesting politics prevailed over truth and possibly hinted at another vote on the bill in the future.
Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell called the commission a "purely political exercise" and suggested focusing on the current administration's policies instead.
Alaska Senator Lisa Murkowski criticized Republican leadership's opposition to the bill, emphasizing the need for accountability for the Jan. 6 events.
House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy and McConnell argued the commission would interfere with other investigations and should examine other violent protests.
The bill, which failed in the Senate, had passed in the Democratic-led House with support from 35 Republican members.
Speaker Nancy Pelosi hinted at the possibility of forming a separate panel to investigate the riot if a bipartisan commission could not be established.
spokespersons: Joe Biden (President of the United States)
Carolyn Maloney (Rep., Chair of the Oversight Committee, New York)
Adam Schiff (Rep., House Intelligence Committee chair, Democrat, California)
Gladys Sicknick (Mother of the late Capitol Police officer Brian Sicknick)
